Derek,

Hmmm...you make interesting points.  I will consider them more deeply and get back to you.

I specifically like your points about "genetic drift".


Jim


--- Derek James <blue5432@...> wrote:
> --- "Jim O'Flaherty, Jr." <jim_oflaherty_jr@...>
> wrote:
> > I think the population evolved according to the
> > definitions you have presented, both your own and
> > of those you cited.
> 
> Okay...but do *you* think it evolved?
>  
> > I also think that there is little utility in
> > agreeing or disagreeing with determining whether
> > this particular population evolved.  
> 
> I disagree.  I think it is extremely important to be
> conceptually clear, for two primary reasons:
> 
> 1) To communicate more effectively with others in the
> field, so that the exchange of ideas is more efficient
> and fruitful
> 
> 2) To understand which features of the process you are
> emulating are inherent in your algorithm.  For
> example, understanding that artificial populations are
> subject to genetic drift just as natural populations
> are helps you better understand the dynamics of your
> system and helps you determine better starting points
> for parameters to try.
> 
> You're working with Fogel's paradigm, which uses an
> extremely small population size (30, correct?).  This
> made me suspicious of Fogel's claims right off the
> bat...a population this small seems like a bad idea
> for a number of reasons, including genetic drift
> (Fogel doesn't actually use a genotype->phenotype
> mapping, but the basic concept still applies).
> 
> > We may end up having to find our own words to
> > describe the process we are choosing to use, because
> > strictly speaking...we are not technically
> > using nature's version of evolution.
> 
> Well, but in those cases where the dynamics of natural
> systems map relatively well to what we're doing, we
> would want to capture that in the language we use,
> wouldn't we?
> 
> For example, why would I use a term other than
> "cooperative coevolution" if that describes the
> dynamics of my system reasonably well?
> 
> Derek
>
